tasks.task: Understanding and selecting between inline and anti-siphon control valves for a sprinkler system.
subtasks: Recognizing the purpose of anti-siphon valves in preventing backflow and protecting drinking water.
Knowing the necessary installation height (above ground) for anti-siphon valves to function correctly.
Understanding the need to protect anti-siphon valves from freezing conditions.
Realizing anti-siphon valves are typically installed in front and back yard manifolds for easy access.
Comprehending the ease of finding and servicing anti-siphon valves due to their manifold installation.
Recognizing the increased pipe usage required when using anti-siphon valves compared to inline valves.
Understanding the advantages of inline control valves, including buried underground protection from freezing.
Noting that inline valves are located closer to sprinkler heads, using less pipe and providing balanced water pressure.
Appreciating the natural landscaping appearance of inline valves due to their valve box cover.
Understanding why inline valves are chosen despite potentially needing a separate backflow protection device.
Recognizing the necessity of a mainline backflow device when using inline valves.
Knowing the infrequent testing and certification requirement for inline backflow protection devices.
Grasping the potential drawback of non-testable backflow devices in anti-siphon valves.
Being aware that some local regulations prohibit anti-siphon valves due to non-testable features.
Considering municipal or water district guidelines before purchasing anti-siphon control valves.
Noting the store's inventory of irrigation products, including various plants and sprinkler needs.
Knowing how to contact customer service for product inquiries through phone or online chat.

tasks.task: Navigating the selection process between inline and anti-siphon valves for a sprinkler system.
subtasks: Evaluating the local climate and freeze protection requirements for valve selection.
Assessing the need for easy access and maintenance of backflow devices.
Considering zoning regulations and local testing requirements for backflow prevention devices.
Weighing the pro's and con's of each valve type, including installation complexity and water pressure distribution.
Deciding on valve type based on sprinkler system design goals and local guidelines.
Confirming compatibility and integration with existing sprinkler system components.
Ensuring the chosen valves meet the required water pressure and flow rates for the sprinkler zones.
Planning for necessary pipe lengths and connections when switching from one valve type to another.
Considering aesthetics and landscaping impacts of valve placement and cover options.
Accounting for the possibility of requiring additional backflow devices when using inline valves or specific system configurations.
Consulting online resources or customer service for tailored advice on valve selection.
